title: VC Daily: Big Tech's Influence on Entrepreneurship
text:
Among her findings:

Inventors are more likely to become entrepreneurs and start a business if they are entering a more competitive market (meaning one not dominated by a massive tech company).

The quality of innovation is higher when the market is less competitive (meaning dominated by a large tech company). Ms. Wang measured the quality of innovation by examining the number of citations a patent received.

Ms. Wang's findings come as U.S. regulators continue to look at big tech's influence on competitive markets.

And now on to the news ...

Top News

Venture's role in China. U.S. firms and their China affiliates are ramping up investment in Chinese semiconductor companies, aiding Beijing's bid for chip-sector dominance and complicating Washington's efforts to preserve America's lead in the critical technology, a Wall Street Journal investigation has found.

U.S. venture-capital firms, chip-industry giants and other private investors participated in 58 investment deals in China's semiconductor industry from 2017 through 2020, more than double the number from the prior four years, according to an analysis of deals data by New York-based research firm Rhodium Group done at the Journal's request.

Major chip company Intel Corp. is among the active investors, backing a Chinese company now called Primarius Technologies Co., which specializes in chip-design tools that U.S. companies currently lead in making, a separate Journal review of data from analytics firm PitchBook Data Inc. shows.

6%

Counterpoint Research in September cut its 2021 growth forecast for world-wide smartphone shipments to 6% from 12% earlier in the year, citing the chip shortage. (WSJ)

CyrusOne Nears Deal to Be Sold to a Private-Equity Buyer

CyrusOne Inc. is nearing a deal to be sold to a private-equity buyer that could value the data-center operator at more than $10 billion, according to people familiar with the matter, WSJ reports. CyrusOne is in advanced talks with at least two groups and could choose a buyer within days assuming the talks don't fall apart, the people said. One group includes KKR & Co. and Global Infrastructure Partners and another, Brookfield Asset Management Inc., the people said.

Record Quitting Fuels Tight Job Market

The U.S. economy has had more than 10 million open jobs since June, an extraordinary stretch of imbalance in the labor market that also includes record numbers of workers quitting their jobs, WSJ reports. As of Nov. 5, there were a projected 11.2 million U.S. job openings, according to estimates from the jobs site Indeed, exceeding 7.4 million unemployed workers in the U.S. labor force last month. The so-called quits rate—a measurement of workers leaving jobs as a share of overall employment—was 3% in September, a record high, Friday's Labor Department data showed, a sign of worker confidence in the job market. Total quits, which reflects the number of jobs that workers left voluntarily, hit another record at 4.4 million.

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on Nov. 17. The program includes an innovation showcase with AB InBev, Keurig Dr Pepper and City Developments Ltd. and a presentation by Jonah Goldman, managing director at Breakthrough Energy. Register here.

Industry News

Funds

Synergis Capital has launched its second crypto-focused fund after raising $50 million for the firm's debut crypto fund in January. The new fund's portfolio includes Magic.link, IntoTheBlock, Forte, Syndicate, Lunarcrush and Art Blocks. The target amount of Synergis Fund II wasn't disclosed.

Canadian media and telecommunications firm Quebecor launched a venture capital arm, asterX, to support startups with the potential to stimulate innovation in Quebecor's core business segments.

People

Food and agriculture investor Finistere Ventures appointed Steve Goldberg as partner. He was previously an operating partner at Venrock.

Actym Therapeutics named Chan Whiting as chief development officer. She was previously senior vice president and head of research and development at Tempest Therapeutics. Berkeley, Calif.-based Actym is backed by investors including Boehringer-Ingelheim Venture Fund, Illumina Ventures, Korea Investment Partners and JLO Ventures.

New Money

Forte, which is building a blockchain-based economic platform for video games, scored $725 million in Series B funding. Sea Capital and Kora Management led the round, which included support from zVentures, Griffin Gaming Partners, Andreessen Horowitz and Tiger Global Management.

Applied Intuition Inc., a developer of software for autonomous vehicle development, raised $175 million in Series D funding at a $3.6 billion valuation. Elad Gil, Addition and Coatue Management co-led the round, which saw participation from Andreessen Horowitz, General Catalyst and Lux Capital.

Stori, a Mexico-based credit-card startup, secured a $125 million oversubscribed Series C round, in addition to $75 million in debt financing. GGV Capital and GIC co-led the Series C portion, which included participation from General Catalyst, Goodwater Capital, Tresalia Capital, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Vision Plus Capital, BAI Capital and Source Code Capital. Community Investment Management provided the debt.

Pigment, a Paris-based planning and forecasting platform for businesses, landed $73 million in Series B funding. Led by Greenoaks, the round included contributions from previous backers FirstMark Capital and Blossom Capital.

CompStak Inc., a New York-based provider of commercial real estate transaction data and analytics, picked up a $50 million Series C round. Investment funds managed by Morgan Stanley Expansion Capital led the funding, which included additional support from Mitsui Fudosan's CVC Fund, Crow Holdings, Canaan Partners and IA Capital.

vivenu GmbH, a Germany-based event ticketing platform, closed a $50 million Series B round. Activant Capital led the investment, which included participation from Balderton Capital, Aurum Fund and Redalpine Venture Partners.

Ankyra Therapeutics, a Boston-based developer of cancer therapies, completed a $45 million Series B round. New investors Borealis Ventures, Fidelity Management & Research Co., GV, Sands Capital Ventures and Spring Mountain Capital were joined by existing backers Polaris Partners and Mithril Capital in the funding. In addition to the new funds, Howard Kaufman was appointed chief medical officer. He was previously head of research and development at Immuneering Corp. Phil Ferneau of Borealis Ventures will join Ankyra's board.

Daily, a San Francisco-based provider of audio and video APIs for developers, raised $40 million in a Series B funding. Renegade Partners led the round, which included participation from Heritage Group, Cendana Capital, Lachy Groom, Tiger Global Management, Freestyle Ventures, Root Ventures, Slack Fund, Moxxie Ventures and others. Roseanne Wincek of Renegade Partners and Lee Edwards of Root Ventures will join the company's board.

Ometria, a customer data and marketing platform, snagged $40 million in Series C funding. Infravia Capital Partners led the round, which included contributions from Octopus Ventures, Sonae IM, Summit Action, Adjuvo and Columbia Lake Partners.

Houm, a Chilean proptech startup, snagged $35 million in Series A funding. Goodwater Capital led the round, which saw participation from Fifth Wall, OneVC, Fen Ventures and others.

Keyway, a New York-based commercial real estate technology platform for small- and medium-sized business owners, was seeded with a $15 million investment. Led by Canvas Ventures, the round included additional support from Montage Ventures, FJ Labs and Crosscut. Rebecca Lynn, general partner at Canvas Ventures, joined the board.

ALEX, a New York-based decentralized finance platform on bitcoin, gathered $5.8 million in new funding led by White Star Capital.

Weflow, a Salesforce productivity platform for revenue teams, grabbed $2.7 million in pre-seed funding led by Cherry Ventures.

Tech News

Elon Musk sells additional Tesla stock worth about $687 million

Facebook is stifling independent report on its impact in India, human rights groups say

U.S. accuses Russian of money laundering for Ryuk ransomware gang

Stuck in the metaverse for 24 hours: Here's what I did

Bitcoin mining noise drives neighbors nuts—a giant dentist drill that won't stop

When the Travis Scott concert stopped, the social-media posts—and conspiracy theories—were just beginning

Around the Web

Sequoia Capital's new structure seems more like VC's natural progression than a game changer (Crunchbase News)
